DataElement.preferredName: Cancer Identification ICD-O Primary Anatomic Site Topography Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The codes that describe the primary site of the tumor being reported using either ICD-O-2 or ICD-O-3.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Cancer Identification ICD-O Primary Anatomic Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The primary site of the tumor being reported using either ICD-O-2 or ICD-O-3.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Identified; having the identity known or established.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The procedure of having an identity established.

Property.preferredName: International Classification of Disease for Oncology Primary Anatomic Site
Property.preferredDefinition: The International Classification of Disease for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com):Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary):Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Named locations of or within the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Body tissue, region, surface, cavity, fluid, organ, or collection of organs.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A text field to specify the ICD-O topography code.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Text; the words of something written.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Division of Cancer Control and Population Sciences

AlternateNames.name: Person with cancer-primary site of cancer, code (ICDO-3) ANN{.N[N]}

ReferenceDocuments.name: Primary Site Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: NAACCR adopted ICD-O-2 as the standard coding system for tumors diagnosed beginning January 1, 1992. In addition, NAACCR recommended that tumors diagnosed prior to 1992 be converted to ICD-O-2.  The topography (primary site) codes have not changed between ICD-O-2 and ICD-O-3.

ReferenceDocuments.name: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
ReferenceDocuments.description: Frtiz A, Percy C, Jack A, Shanmugaratnam K, Sobin L, Parkin D, et al., editors.  International  Classification of Diseases for Oncology.  Third Edition. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2000.
